audio_caption: The audio clip begins with dramatic orchestral music, setting an epic mood with prominent brass instruments. A male speaker, identified as "Professor Jim Caffey," introduces "Chapter six" on "Astronomical Instruments," speaking in a calm and professional tone. The dramatic music then returns, emphasizing a shift back to the prior epic feel.

The clip begins with a calm, informative male speaker discussing the Hubble Space Telescope and its long duration in space, soon to be replaced. He then transitions to describing a region of space, pointing out the Orion Nebula, Orion's belt, shoulders, and feet, explaining their locations. The focus is on the Orion Nebula in relation to the belt and a particular star, with the speaker mentioning how the nebula appears differently in different wavelengths.

The audio clip begins with speech describing pre-telescopic observatories. The speaker, who sounds like a male, continues describing the formation of an image by a simple lens. The background contains consistent breathing sounds, which may indicate the proximity of the speaker.

The clip features one male speaker explaining the difference between refracting and reflecting telescopes, stating that "refracting telescopes thin light through a lens" while "a reflecting telescope reflects light off of a mirror through another mirror then goes through an eyepiece." He adds that a reflecting telescope allows for different areas of focus. The speaker has a neutral tone.

The clip features a single speaker, who appears to be male, explaining different aspects of a telescope and its parts. He begins by mentioning the "aperture" and "eyepiece" for focus, then describes a "very large telescope mirror" that will be used in the "European Southern Observatory's very large telescope." His tone is informative and somewhat academic.

The audio features a single male speaker with an informative tone, discussing names of light tunes, instruments, and telescopes. He mentions the Palomar 5-meter reflector and the Gemini North 8-meter telescope. He concludes with the phrase "36 eyes are better than one," exhibiting a slight increase in intensity.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing the construction of telescopes, specifically mentioning the use of segmented mirrors to create large telescopes. The speaker mentions gluing the segments together and using a specific example of a telescope in Hawaii.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing George Hale and his work on telescope construction. He mentions the world's largest refractor bending telescope, located in Chicago. The speaker then states that most observatories are built as high up on mountains as possible. He's interrupted by background music.

The clip begins with a single male speaker describing a "high and dry site" in Chile's Atacama Desert, mentioning the European Southern Observatory. He speaks about pistons on the back of telescope mirrors used to correct for the atmosphere and the importance of CCDs as silicon wafers sensitive to light. Transitioning to the subject of infrared, he notes that they can see hands in a bag very clearly due to heat radiation. He describes a prism spectrometer and its function of splitting white light into a colorful rainbow.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker introducing "the first radio telescope," describing it as "very basic" and noting its use by Jansky in discovering radio radiation from the Milky Way. He then proceeds to describe a radio image, pointing out a galaxy in the middle that doesn't give off much radio information, but notes two lobes projecting far out into space. Finally, there's a sound effect.

The audio clip begins with a single speaker, seemingly male, describing the Green Bank telescope, the large millimeter array, and options for radio telescopes. The speaker emphasizes linking them all together so the Earth acts like a radio dish. He then mentions the Arecibo Observatory as the largest radio and radar dish.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing placing observatories into the upper atmosphere, specifically mentioning "Sophia" and how it enables one to get above Earth's water vapor, which he describes as "blinding to infrared light." His tone is informative and slightly subdued. Following this speech, there is the sound of speech from a male.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the "Spitzer space telescope" which "does infrared images", then transitioning to a description of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field, noting it shows "area of space...13 billion years ago" as looking back into time. He then mentions that "The Chandra X-ray Satellite does the same thing, but for X-rays". The speaker then shifts to talking about "coming up in 2021" the "James Webb Space Telescope" launch.

The clip begins with a male speaker who mentions "rigorous testing" and refers to the "European extremely large telescope" currently under construction in Chile. He then thanks the audience for joining him for Chapter 6. The next speaker, another male, asks if the audience enjoyed the "10-minute astronomy" episode, and invites them to check out more videos on his channel, as well as hit the "subscribe" button. The audio then ends with an electronic sound effect.
